'''Ripple''' is a [[real-time gross settlement]] system, [[foreign exchange market|currency exchange]] and [[remittance]] network created by [[Ripple (company)|Ripple Labs Inc.]], a US-based technology company. Released in 2012, Ripple is built upon a [[distributed computing|distributed]] [[open source software|open source]] [[Communication protocol|protocol]], and supports tokens representing [[fiat currency]], [[cryptocurrency]], [[commodity|commodities]], or other units of value such as frequent flier miles or mobile minutes.<ref name="virsutalcurrentcy">{{cite web|title=Ripple Labs Banks $3.5M for Open-Source Payments System and Virtual Currency|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/DJFVW00020131112e9bcncf1w|work=The Wall Street Journal Pro|publisher=Dow Jones & Company|date=November 12, 2013|accessdate=January 28, 2014}}</ref>  Ripple purports to enable "secure, instantly and nearly free global financial transactions of any size with no chargebacks."

The ledger employs the decentralized native cryptocurrency known as XRP, which {{Asof|2018|09|lc=yes|df=|since=}} was the second largest coin by [[market capitalization]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/ripple-co-founders-token-selloff-accelerates-1537788600 |title=Ripple Co-Founder's Token Selloff Accelerates |last=Geron |first=Tomio |date=2018-09-24 |work=Wall Street Journal |access-date=September 26, 2018 |language=en-US |issn=0099-9660}}</ref><ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/04/technology/bitcoin-ripple.html Rise of Bitcoin Competitor Ripple Creates Wealth to Rival Zuckerberg]</ref> Ripple has been adopted by banks and [[payment network]]s as settlement infrastructure technology.<ref name="nytimerush">{{cite news | title=The rush to coin virtual money with real value | last=Popper | first=Nathaniel | work=The New York Times | url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2013/11/11/the-rush-to-coin-virtual-money-with-real-value/?_php=true&_type=blogs&_r=0 | accessdate=January 26, 2014 | publisher=[[The New York Times Company]] }}</ref> Ripple relies on a common shared ledger, which is a distributed database storing information about all Ripple accounts. The network is "managed by a network of independent validating servers that constantly compare their transaction records." Servers could belong to anyone, including banks or market makers.<ref name="clegsb">
{{cite news
| title       = Chris Larsen: Money Without Borders
| first       = Edmund L.
| last        = Andrews
| url         = http://www.gsb.stanford.edu/insights/chris-larsen-money-without-borders
| publisher   = [[Stanford Graduate School of Business]]
| date        = September 24, 2013
| accessdate  = April 10, 2015
}}</ref> Ripple validates accounts and balances instantly for payment transmission and delivers payment notification with very little latency (within a few seconds).<ref name="nortificationlatency">{{cite news | last=Simonite | first=Tom | date=April 11, 2013 | title=Big-name investors back effort to build a better Bitcoin | work=MIT Technology Review | url=http://www.technologyreview.com/news/513606/big-name-investors-back-effort-to-build-a-better-bitcoin/ | accessdate=January 26, 2014 }}</ref> Payments are irreversible, and there are no chargebacks.<ref name="norchargebacksfaxtcoexist">{{cite web|last=Schwartz|first=Ariel|title=Bitcoin 2.0: Can Ripple Make Digital Currency Mainstream?|url=http://www.fastcoexist.com/1682032/bitcoin-20-can-ripple-make-digital-currency-mainstream|publisher=Fast Company|accessdate=February 2, 2014}}</ref>

For its creation and development of the Ripple protocol (RTXP) and the Ripple payment/exchange network Ripple Labs was named as one of 2014's 50 Smartest Companies in the February 2014 edition of ''[[MIT Technology Review]]''.<ref name="bergstensmartestmiet">{{cite web|last=Bergstein|first=Brian|title=50 Smartest Companies|url=http://www2.technologyreview.com/tr50/2014/|publisher=MIT Technology Review|accessdate=March 12, 2014}}</ref> A scientific study made by two researchers from Stanford and Stockholm University that studied the money production from an energy consumption point of view and a macroeconomic level stated that running a server on Ripple was comparable to the energy needs of running an email server.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://papers.netrogenic.com/sid/eco-friendly-money.pdf|title=How Eco friendly is our money and is there an alternative?|last1=Leopold|first1=Sid John|last2=Englesson|first2=Niclas|date=November 27, 2017|access-date=August 27, 2018}}</ref>

== History ==
Ripple was conceived by [[Jed McCaleb]] and built by Arthur Britto and David Schwartz who then approached Ryan Fugger who had debuted in 2005 as a financial service to provide secure payment options to members of an online community via a global network.<ref name="peck2013">{{cite web|url=http://spectrum.ieee.org/telecom/internet/ripple-credit-system-could-help-or-harm-bitcoin|title=Ripple Could Help or Harm Bitcoin|last=Peck|first=Morgan|date=January 14, 2013|work=IEEE Spectrum|publisher=[[Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers]]|accessdate=January 27, 2014}}</ref><ref name="ripllecouldmakebitcoin">{{cite web|url=http://motherboard.vice.com/blog/the-ripple-economy-could-make-bitcoin-great|title=Ripple Could Make Bitcoin Great (or Destroy It)|last=Liu|first=Alec|publisher=Motherboard|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140207195306/http://motherboard.vice.com/blog/the-ripple-economy-could-make-bitcoin-great|archivedate=February 7, 2014|deadurl=yes|accessdate=January 27, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Fugger had developed a system called OpenCoin which would transform into Ripple.<ref name="clegsb" /><ref name="clcnielsen" /><ref name="clcnielsen">
{{cite news
| title       = Lessons in Innovation Leadership: Chris Larsen
| first       = Dr. Venkatesh
| last        = Bala
| url         = http://www.nielsen.com/us/en/insights/news/2014/lessons-in-innovation-leadership-chris-larsen.html
| newspaper   = [[Nielsen Holdings N.V.|Nielsen]]
| publisher   = The Cambridge Group
| date        = October 8, 2014
| accessdate  = June 10, 2015
}}</ref> The company also created its own form of digital currency referred to as [[XRP]] in a manner similar to bitcoin, using the currency to allow financial institutions to transfer money with negligible fees and wait-time.<ref name="clfFortun">
{{cite news
| title       = Isn't one Internet enough?
| first       = Adam
| last        = Lashinsky
| url         = http://fortune.com/2014/08/22/ripple-virtual-currency/
| newspaper   = [[Fortune Magazine]]
| date        = August 22, 2014
| accessdate  = April 10, 2015
}}</ref>

Ripple Labs continued as the primary contributors of code to the consensus verification system behind Ripple, which can "integrate with banksâ€™ existing networks."<ref name="clhanker">
{{cite news
| title       = Ripple Labs CEO looks to revolutionise online payments
| first       = Jane
| last        = Cooper
| url         = http://www.thebanker.com/Techvision/Ripple-Labs-CEO-looks-to-revolutionise-online-payments
| newspaper   = [[The Banker]]
| date        = March 11, 2014
| accessdate  = April 10, 2015
}}</ref> Since 2013, the protocol has been adopted by an increasing number of financial institutions to "[offer] an alternative [[remittance]] option" to consumers.<ref name="clmenters">
{{cite news
| title       = Alternative Money Mover Ripple Labs Enters U.S. Banking System
| first       = Matt
| last        = Scully
| url         = http://www.americanbanker.com/issues/179_185/alternative-money-mover-ripple-labs-enters-us-banking-system-1070201-1.html
| newspaper   = [[American Banker]]
| date        = September 24, 2014
| accessdate  = June 16, 2015
}}</ref>
By December 2014 Ripple Labs began working with global payments service Earthport, combining Ripple's software with Earthport's payment services system.  The partnership marked the first network usage of the Ripple protocol.<ref name="nrdwsjbit">
{{cite news
| title       = BitBeat: Ripple Partners With Global Payments Service Earthport
| first1      = Michael J. |last1 = Casey
| first2      = Paul |last2 = Vigna
| url         = https://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2014/12/04/bitbeat-ripple-partners-with-global-payments-service-earthport/
| newspaper   = [[Wall Street Journal]]
| publisher   =
| date        = December 4, 2014
| accessdate  = June 9, 2015
}}</ref> On December 29, 2017, XRP briefly became the second largest cryptocurrency, with a market capitalization of US$73 billion.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ripple's 53% Surge Makes It the Second-Biggest Cryptocurrency|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-12-29/ripple-s-ris-is-poised-to-rain-on-ether-s-flippening-parade|website=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] |first=Kailey |last=Leinz |date=December 29, 2017 |access-date=February 14, 2019}}</ref>

A class-action lawsuit was filed against Ripple in May 2018 "alleging that it led a scheme to raise hundreds of millions of dollars through unregistered sales of its XRP tokens. [creating] billions of coins 'out of thin air' and then profited by selling them to the public in 'what is essentially a never-ending initial coin offering'."<ref name=bloomberg20180504>{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-05-04/ripple-hit-with-class-action-suit-over-never-ending-ico |title=Ripple Hit With Class-Action Suit Over 'Never Ending ICO' |first=Lily |last=Katz |date=May 4, 2018 |website=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] |access-date=January 27, 2019}}</ref>
